tweets.content: @Lebowskiana: Disaster risk data should be open by default @vdeparday @GFDRR #IODC16

@geohacker: Tomorrow starting 9.30 I'm organising a pre-event on open map data for disaster response featuring @hotosm. #IODC16 http://opendatacon.org/agenda/pre-events/open-data-disaster-response-humanitarian-openstreetmap-team/ …
@TheGovLab: "Disaster risk data should be open by default, accessible & communicated in ways that meets needs of diverse users"-Vivien Deparday@ #IODC16pic.twitter.com/NC8VOHJ121

info: The session was organized by Georg Neumann from Open Contracting and had lightning talks from Canada, Colombia, France, Mexico City, Mexico, Moldova, Nigeria, Paraguay, Ukraine, UK, Vietnam, and Zambia, and deep dives into shared examples.

session.description: The OpenStreetMap project is one of the largest open data projects. The HOT, tackles worldwide mapping challenges that arise from natural disasters as a team, where the set of tools available allow almost everyone to contribute.

conference_notes: The Humanitarian OpenStreetMap Team (HOT) applies the principles of open source and open data sharing for humanitarian response and economic development. OpenStreetMap is the one of the largest open data projects with millions of contributors, mapping different parts of the world. This session will focus on some of the recent HOT ‘activations’, stories from volunteers and the field, anecdotes about the tools, data, and processes.
name: Open data for Disaster Reponse - Humanitarian OpenStreetMap Team
